title: Metal that could have revolutionised life ‘disappears’, Harvard scientists reveal - 9news.com.au
text:
Metal that could have revolutionised life ‘disappears’, Harvard scientists reveal By 9NEWS Harvard scientists have revealed their revolutionary metal has disappeared. 
A minuscule piece of possibly the rarest and most valuable material on the planet, which could have revolutionised life as we know it, has vanished. 
Harvard scientists were dealt a crushing blow after something went wrong while they studied the sample of metallic hydrogen they reportedly created last month, according to the Independent . 
Metallic hydrogen could be used to make a more powerful type of rocket fuel and allow for greater exploration of the solar system. 
The sample was being kept between two tiny diamonds at a pressure greater than that found at Earth’s centre, and a temperature close to absolute zero. 
Scientists revealed they heard a small "click" as they tested the pressure with a low-power laser, indicating one of the diamonds had turned into a fine dust like "baking soda". 
Professor Isaac Silvera said his "heart fell" when he heard they had lost the sample. 
"I’ve never seen a diamond shatter like that. It was so powdered on the surface, it looked like baking soda or something like that," he said. 
"I didn’t believe it was diamond, it was such a fine powder." 
Despite some physicists questioning the claim the sample was ever created, there are a number of reasons no evidence of metallic hydrogen remains. 
One is that the small sample is lost in the metal gasket it was contained in. 
It could also point to the theory that metallic hydrogen is unstable and turns into a gas at room temperature and normal pressure. 
The latter theory means it would crush hopes of a new wonder material. 
Despite the loss, Professor Silva and his team will attempt their experiment in the next few weeks and are confident the results will be repeated. © Nine Digital Pty Ltd 2017
